span: hat clip youjust  heard from the veteran describing what it was like to come back to the US… that’s from an initiative called One Small Step
label: ['Explain']

span: Our effort to address just how divided we’ve become.
label: ['Explain']

span: It brings strangers with opposing political beliefs together for a conversation – not to argue about politics… but just to learn about each other’s lives.
label: ['Explain']

span: We don’t expect them to or even want them or ask them to agree by the end of the conversation.
label: ['Explain']

span: That’s Mary Bess Ser…. she works on One Small Step.
label: ['Explain']

span: We’re not asking people to come to any sort of common ground
label: ['Explain']

span: We just want people to talk.
label: ['Explain']

span: Because… we HAVE stopped talking to each other
label: ['Explain']

span: . A lot of us have a tendency to shut out people we don’t agree with… so One Small Step asks us to do the opposite… to actually get to know each other.
label: ['Explain']

span: The basis of the whole conversation is, you know, yes, we probably disagree on most things, but we’re having this conversation anyway.
label: ['Explain']

span: And by the end of it, We’ll see what happens.
label: ['Explain']

span: You know, these days the voices telling us that we’re supposed to hate each other are so loud… and so pervasive… One Small Step really feels like David taking on Goliath… but we’ve never shied from a challenge before…
label: ['Explain']

span: And there’s scientific evidence that something like this can make a difference
label: ['Explain']

span: One Small Step is rooted in a psychological concept called Contact Theory.
label: ['Explain']

span: The idea is that under very specific circumstances… when people who consider themselves enemies are put together one on one… they can actually come out the other side of that experience understanding and accepting each other… and sometimes they even become friends.
label: ['Explain']

span: One of the keys is that phrase “very specific circumstances” – so StoryCorps tweaked our interview process to create a space where these conversations can happen.
label: ['Explain']

span: Almost all StoryCorps interviews are between two people who know and care about each other… but One Small Step interviews are between strangers.
label: ['Explain']

span: Here’s Mary Bess again…
label: ['Explain']

span: The fact that they’re strangers really makes it less threatening.
label: ['Explain']

span: So say you have a really hard time talking about politics with your mother – that may or may not be my story –  it’s easier to have this conversation with a stranger because there’s no relationship at stake
label: ['Explain']

span: You come to the table with a clean slate.
label: ['Explain']

span: Here’s how it works – people sign up online – there’s a questionnaire that asks them to rate how they feel about social and economic issues… how important religion is in their lives…
label: ['Explain']

span: hey can select from a list of terms to identify themselves… things like parent, grandparent or veteran.
label: ['Explain']

span: And they write a short bio… describing themselves in their own words – and that gets shared with their interview partner.
label: ['Explain']

span: Then someone from StoryCorps – like Mary Bess – matches them up with a stranger.
label: ['Explain']

label: ['Explain']

span: Really they show up to the interview, you know, not knowing at all what to expect, and usually people realize that they’ve come to the table with a lot of assumptions.

span: At StoryCorps he told his daughter, Robin, about something that happened in high school.

span: I’m riding to school with my oldest brother, and on the way to school, I’m putting glitter all over my face.

label: ['Explain']

label: ['Explain']

label: ['Explain']

span: So my dad drove up to the high school.
label: ['Explain']

span: And he had his farmer jeans on and they had cow crap on them, and he had his clodhopper boots on.
label: ['Explain']

span: And when I saw him coming, I ducked around the hall and hid from him.
label: ['Explain']

span: And it wasn’t because of what I was wearing, it was because of what he was wearing.
label: ['Explain']

span: So, the assembly goes well, and I climb in the car and I’m riding home with my father.

span: My father says to me, ”I was walking down the hall this morning, and I saw a kid that looked a lot like you ducking around the hall to avoid his dad.
label: ['Explain']

span: But I know it wasn’t you, cause you would never do that to your dad.”
label: ['Explain']

span: And I squirmed in my seat, and I finally busted out and I said, ”Well dad, did you have to wear your cow-crap jeans to my assembly?”
label: ['Explain']

span: And he said, ”Look, everybody knows I’m a dairy farmer. This is who I am.”
label: ['Explain']

span: And he looked me square in the eye.
label: ['Explain']

span: And then he said, ”Now, how bout you? When you’re a full-grown man, who are you gonna go out with at night?”
label: ['Explain']

span: And I said, ”I don’t know.”
label: ['Explain']

span: And he said, ”I think you do know, and it’s not gonna be that McGlaughlin girl that’s been making goo-goo eyes at you but you won’t even pick up the damn telephone.”
label: ['Explain']

span: “Now, I’m gonna tell you something today, and you might not know what to think of it now, but you’re gonna remember when you’re an adult. Don’t sneak. Because if you sneak, like you did today, it means you think you’re doing the wrong thing. And if you run around spending your whole life thinking that you’re doing the wrong thing, then you’ll ruin your immortal soul.”
label: ['Explain']

span: And out of all the things a father in 1959 could have told his gay son, my father tells me to be proud of myself and not sneak.

span: My reaction at the time was to get out in the hay field and pretend like I was as much of a man as I could be.

label: ['Explain']

span: I had the patron saint of dads for sissies, and no, I didn’t know at the time, but I know it now.

span: That clip youjust  heard from the veteran describing what it was like to come back to the US… that’s from an initiative called One Small Step.
label: ['Explain']

span: Our effort to address just how divided we’ve become.
label: ['Explain']

span: It brings strangers with opposing political beliefs together for a conversation – not to argue about politics… but just to learn about each other’s lives.
label: ['Explain']

span: We don’t expect them to or even want them or ask them to agree by the end of the conversation.
label: ['Statement']

span: That’s Mary Bess Ser…. she works on One Small Step.
label: ['Explain']

span: We’re not asking people to come to any sort of common ground. We just want people to talk.
label: ['Statement']

span: Because… we HAVE stopped talking to each other.
label: ['Explain']

span: A lot of us have a tendency to shut out people we don’t agree with… so One Small Step asks us to do the opposite… to actually get to know each other.
label: ['Explain']

span: The basis of the whole conversation is, you know, yes, we probably disagree on most things, but we’re having this conversation anyway.
label: ['Explain']

span: And by the end of it, We’ll see what happens.
label: ['Explain']

span: You know, these days the voices telling us that we’re supposed to hate each other are so loud… and so pervasive… One Small Step really feels like David taking on Goliath… but we’ve never shied from a challenge before…
label: ['Explain']

span: And there’s scientific evidence that something like this can make a difference.
label: ['Explain']

span: One Small Step is rooted in a psychological concept called Contact Theory.
label: ['Explain']

span: The idea is that under very specific circumstances… when people who consider themselves enemies are put together one on one… they can actually come out the other side of that experience understanding and accepting each other… and sometimes they even become friends.
label: ['Explain']

span: One of the keys is that phrase “very specific circumstances” – so StoryCorps tweaked our interview process to create a space where these conversations can happen.
label: ['Explain']

span: Almost all StoryCorps interviews are between two people who know and care about each other… but One Small Step interviews are between strangers.
label: ['Explain']

span: Here’s Mary Bess again…
label: ['Explain']

span: The fact that they’re strangers really makes it less threatening.
label: ['Statement']

span: So say you have a really hard time talking about politics with your mother – that may or may not be my story –  it’s easier to have this conversation with a stranger because there’s no relationship at stake.
label: ['Explain']

span: You come to the table with a clean slate.
label: ['Explain']

span: Here’s how it works – people sign up online – there’s a questionnaire that asks them to rate how they feel about social and economic issues… how important religion is in their lives…
label: ['Explain']

span: They can select from a list of terms to identify themselves… things like parent, grandparent or veteran.
label: ['Explain']

span: And they write a short bio… describing themselves in their own words – and that gets shared with their interview partner.
label: ['Explain']

span: Then someone from StoryCorps – like Mary Bess – matches them up with a stranger.
label: ['Explain']

span: There’s a real person doing the pairing… not an algorithm.
label: ['Explain']

span: They don’t see the reason why we’ve matched them.
label: ['Explain']

span: Really they show up to the interview, you know, not knowing at all what to expect, and usually people realize that they’ve come to the table with a lot of assumptions.
label: ['Explain']

span: Here’s one example.
label: ['Statement']

span: So there ARE some other ways One Small Step interviews are different from standard StoryCorps conversations…
label: ['Explain']

span: Each One Small Step interview starts with the participants reading each other’s bios out loud…
label: ['Explain']

span: And then a trained facilitator guides them through the conversation with questions from a list designed specifically for One Small Step.
label: ['Explain']

span: One of the questions is can you describe in your own words, your personal political values?
label: ['Closed-ended']

span: The way it’s phrased you’re asked to talk about why you care about something, why it’s important to you, why you believe X, Y, or Z.
label: ['Explain']

span: So you’re still talking about your own life.
label: ['Explain']

span: You’re still telling stories, you know, how your grandfather influenced you, or, you know, you grew up poor.
label: ['Explain']

span: It takes politics out of a win and lose sort of binary right?
label: ['Confirmation']

span: Right.
label: ['Response']

span: And makes it about understanding, which is, like, a completely different approach
label: ['Statement']

span: Yeah, I mean you can still walk out of the room and think, you know, that person everything they stand for is completely wrong, but, somehow, I enjoyed speaking with them, or somehow I kind of respect them.

span: Sometimes people say, well, I didn’t see fireworks, it didn’t change me, but they really enjoyed the other person’s company and they were surprised by that, or They really felt like they understood each other and that really surprised them.

Earlier this year, in a “Mr Isay Goes to Washington” moment… Dave brought One Small Step to the annual baseball game between members of Congress at Nationals stadium in DC… and he showed a video on the jumbotron challenging them to participate… and some of them actually did…

span: But for those of who get to do this work… we’ve been able to listen to thousands of these interviews, thousands of  grandparents… or parents or couples and absorb basically generations of wisdom… And I don’t know if I’ve ever told you this but I actually used to keep a folder of little clips from interviews whenever I heard little gems … that I just wanted to keep for myself, stuff I could use in my own life.

label: ['Open-ended']
